Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Microfocus Single-Crystal Diffractometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) programs, Miami University at Oxford will acquire a microfocus X-ray diffractometer. In general, an X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles, and provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. The studies described here will impact a number of areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of chemistry, biochemistry and geology graduate and undergraduate students as well as postdoctoral fellows.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) integrating paramagnetic resonance of high-spin cobalt systems using trispyrazolylborates and trispyrazolymethanes as ligands; (b) investigating the structure of cation and anion solid solutions in apatite; (c) studying surface structure induced dissymmetrization during crystal growth; (d) investigating decavanadates; (e) preparing large molecules with complex three-dimensional structures; (f) developing catalytic methods to affect difficult organic transformations; and (g) merging transition metal and organocatalysis for asymmetric organic transformations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Acquisition of the new, state-of-the-art, single-crystal X-ray diffractometer has greatly enhanced the ability of students and faculty at Miami University to do transformative research in X-ray crystallography and the related fields of mineralogy, chemistry, and solid state physics. All of these fields require atomic-scale structural elucidation of complex materials to drive research. Projects that have been and will be facilitated by the new diffractometer include basic knowledge in the origins of molecular magnetism, metallobiochemistry, structural and environmental mineralogy, ordered organic materials, pharmaceutical development and chemical catalysis. This instrument has already increased synergistic activities and collaboration among the PIs, and across disciplines.

Examples of major accomplishments that adress intellectual merit include 1) the crystal structure of cation and anion solid solutions in apatite and apatite group minerals, such as the OH-Cl-F anion ternary. Our results have elucidated previously unrecognized structural complexities that are significant to using apatite as a recorder or water and halogen activities in magmas on the moon and Mars, and in understanding the role of fluorine in the prevention of dental caries.  2) coordination complexes of Co(II), to generate a better understanding of the link between the physical and electronic structure in these electronically complex systems. The use of Co(II) in modern materials and industrial catalysts is common, and some of the more interesting systems under study make use of the conformational flexibility afforded by five-fold coordination. The ultimate goal is to tie physical structural modulations to easily measurable modulations of electronic structure, via EPR and solution NMR. Critical to this analysis are the precise metrics that can only be provided by X-ray crystallography. The breoader impacts include traning of students, postdoctoral reserchers and young faculty. Scores of students have already been trained in the use of the instument and are empolying it in their graduate and undergraduate reserch.
